claims.text: Human-induced global warming is a major underlying factor for changing weather patterns.
The 2015 Paris Agreement aims to limit global warming to well below 2 degrees Celsius, preferably to 1.5 degrees Celsius.
Increased human consumption of fossil fuels since the industrial revolution has led to more greenhouse gases being released.
Heat waves are 10 times more likely now according to the UK's Met Office.
Global CO2 emissions must be at half of their 2010 levels by 2030 to meet climate targets.
Earth's weather cycles have become increasingly erratic and severe in recent years.
Heat waves have more than doubled in duration in the past 50 years.
Droughts are becoming more common and severe in some areas due to climate change.
Individual rainfall events are becoming heavier across the world, falling in shorter and more intense bursts.
The 1.5 degrees Celsius target is increasingly moving out of reach due to ongoing extreme weather events.

Global CO2 emissions must be at half of their 2010 levels by 2030 to meet climate targets.

Droughts are becoming more common and severe in some areas due to climate change.
Individual rainfall events are becoming heavier across the world, falling in shorter and more intense bursts.
The 1.5 degrees Celsius target is increasingly moving out of reach due to ongoing extreme weather events.

claim_reports.claim_text: Human-induced global warming is a major underlying factor for changing weather patterns.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that human-induced global warming is a major underlying factor for changing weather patterns. NASA, NOAA, and Earthjustice all confirm that human activities, particularly through greenhouse gas emissions, are significantly impacting weather patterns, leading to increased frequency of extreme weather events and changes in precipitation.

supports.title: Evidence - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that human-induced global warming is a significant factor in changing weather patterns, as it highlights the unprecedented rate of warming due to human activities and the resulting widespread changes in the climate system.
supports.snippet: There is unequivocal evidence that Earth is warming at an unprecedented rate. Human activity is the principal cause.

supports.title: Climate change impacts - NOAA
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that human-induced climate change is currently affecting weather patterns, leading to changes in precipitation and increased frequency of extreme weather events like droughts and floods.
supports.snippet: Climate change affects the environment in many different ways, including rising temperatures, sea level rise, drought, flooding, and more. These events affect ...

supports.title: How Climate Change Is Fueling Extreme Weather - Earthjustice
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence clearly indicates that human activity, particularly through carbon emissions, is causing rapid climate changes that contribute to extreme weather patterns. This includes stronger storms, increased wildfires, and more severe droughts, all linked to rising global temperatures.
supports.snippet: Human activity is causing rapid changes to our global climate that are contributing to extreme weather conditions.

unclear.title: Climate change: global temperature
unclear.evidence_summary: Human activities, principally through emissions of greenhouse gases, have unequivocally caused global warming, with global surface ...
unclear.snippet: Human activities, principally through emissions of greenhouse gases, have unequivocally caused global warming, with global surface ...

unclear.title: The Effects of Climate Change - NASA Science
unclear.evidence_summary: Scientists predict global temperature increases from human-made greenhouse gases will continue. Severe weather damage will also increase and ...
unclear.snippet: Scientists predict global temperature increases from human-made greenhouse gases will continue. Severe weather damage will also increase and ...

unclear.title: Human Impacts on the Environment: A Focus on Climate Change
unclear.evidence_summary: Human activities are driving large scale changes in terrestrial and aquatic environments through pollution, water withdrawals, the hunting and harvesting of ...
unclear.snippet: Human activities are driving large scale changes in terrestrial and aquatic environments through pollution, water withdrawals, the hunting and harvesting of ...

claim_reports.claim_text: The 2015 Paris Agreement aims to limit global warming to well below 2 degrees Celsius, preferably to 1.5 degrees Celsius.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence from multiple high-reliability sources confirms that the 2015 Paris Agreement aims to limit global warming to well below 2 degrees Celsius, with a preference for 1.5 degrees Celsius. This is explicitly stated in the UNFCCC documentation, the IPCC report, and the Climate Action Tracker.

supports.title: The Paris Agreement | UNFCCC
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the Paris Agreement aims to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius, stating that greenhouse gas emissions must peak before 2025 and decline significantly by 2030 to achieve this goal.
supports.snippet: To limit global warming to 1.5°C, greenhouse gas emissions must peak before 2025 at the latest and decline 43% by 2030. The Paris Agreement is a landmark in the ...

supports.title: Global Warming of 1.5 ºC —
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the 2015 Paris Agreement aims to limit global warming to well below 2 degrees Celsius, with a preference for limiting it to 1.5 degrees Celsius.
supports.snippet: An IPCC special report on the impacts of global warming of 1.5 °C above pre-industrial levels and related global greenhouse gas emission pathways.

supports.title: Paris temperature goal - Climate Action Tracker
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the Paris Agreement includes a temperature limit of well below 2 degrees Celsius, with a preference for limiting warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius, as it originated from concerns about the impacts of 2°C warming.
supports.snippet: The origin of the 1.5°C Paris Agreement limit derived from the concern amongst the vulnerable countries about the adverse consequences of a 2°C warming level.

claim_reports.claim_text: Increased human consumption of fossil fuels since the industrial revolution has led to more greenhouse gases being released.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence from multiple high-reliability sources consistently confirms that increased human consumption of fossil fuels since the industrial revolution has significantly raised greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere, contributing to climate change.

supports.title: CO2 emissions since Industrial Revolution - Statista
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that human activities, particularly the burning of fossil fuels since the industrial revolution, have significantly increased greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere, leading to climate change.
supports.snippet: Global CO₂ emissions from human activities have risen enormously since the Industrial Revolution began in 1750, to more than 35 GtCO₂ per ...

supports.title: CO₂ and Greenhouse Gas Emissions - Our World in Data
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that since the industrial revolution, human activities, particularly the burning of fossil fuels, have significantly increased greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere, which is linked to rising global temperatures.
supports.snippet: Human greenhouse gas emissions have increased global average temperatures · Global emissions have increased rapidly over the last 50 years and have not yet ...

supports.title: Scientists understood physics of climate change in the 1800s
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the burning of fossil fuels has resulted in a significant increase in carbon dioxide emissions, which aligns with the claim about increased greenhouse gas release due to human consumption since the industrial revolution.
supports.snippet: Burning more and more fossil fuels – coal and eventually oil and gas – added an ever-increasing amount of carbon dioxide into the air.

supports.title: The History of Carbon Dioxide Emissions | World Resources Institute
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that since the industrial revolution, human activities, particularly the burning of fossil fuels, have significantly increased greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere, leading to climate change.
supports.snippet: Recent data reveals that global CO2 emissions were 182 times higher in 2022 than they were in 1850, around the time the Industrial Revolution was underway.

claim_reports.claim_text: Heat waves are 10 times more likely now according to the UK's Met Office.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The UK's Met Office indicates that heatwave days over 40°C are now ten times more likely due to climate change, confirming the claim. This is supported by multiple high-reliability sources, including the World Economic Forum and BBC reports, which affirm the increased likelihood of extreme heat events.

supports.title: Britain's heatwave even be possible without climate change?
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the UK Met Office suggests that heatwave days over 40°C are now ten times more likely due to climate change, confirming the claim.
supports.snippet: The UK Met Office suggests that heatwave days over 40°C are ten times more likely to happen in the UK as a result of climate change.

supports.title: Extreme weather is the UK's new normal, says Met Office - BBC
supports.evidence_summary: The Met Office indicates that the UK is experiencing more frequent extreme weather events, including heatwaves, due to climate change, suggesting that heat waves are indeed becoming more common, although it does not specify that they are exactly 10 times more likely.
supports.snippet: The UK is breaking heat and rainfall records increasingly frequently as its climate continues to warm, the Met Office has warned.

supports.title: Climate breakdown made UK heatwave 10 times more likely, study ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that climate change has significantly increased the likelihood of extreme heat events, including heatwaves, in the UK, with the Met Office suggesting that the chance of experiencing 40°C days has risen substantially due to human-induced climate change.
supports.snippet: Climate breakdown made the recent record UK heatwave 10 times more likely, researchers have found. ... Met Office found the chance of seeing 40C ...

mixed.title: Heatwave in England to bring temperatures above 32°C (89.6°F)
mixed.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that climate change has significantly increased the likelihood of heatwaves, with a study showing that the 2022 UK heatwave was made 10 times more likely due to human-driven climate change. Additionally, the ongoing June 2025 heatwave is also linked to climate change, which has made such high temperatures 100 times more likely, supporting the claim about the increased frequency of heatwaves.
mixed.snippet: Study finds climate change made June 2025 heatwave in England 10 times more likely and temperatures above 32°C (89.6°F) 100 times more ...

mixed.title: UK and Global extreme events – Heatwaves - Met Office
mixed.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the frequency and intensity of heat extremes, including heatwaves, have increased globally, with a high probability attributed to human influence. However, it does not specifically quantify the likelihood of heatwaves being 10 times more likely in the UK as claimed.
mixed.snippet: The AR6 report states that it is virtually certain (over 99% probability) that the frequency and intensity of hot extremes have increased on a global scale ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Global CO2 emissions must be at half of their 2010 levels by 2030 to meet climate targets.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence presents a mixed picture regarding the claim that global CO2 emissions must be halved from 2010 levels by 2030. On one hand, multiple sources, including the IEA and Climate Action Tracker, support the need for a 45% reduction to meet climate targets. On the other hand, the IEA and IPCC indicate that current climate pledges are projected to increase emissions by 10.6% by 2030, contradicting the claim.

refutes.title: Executive summary – Net Zero Roadmap: A Global Pathway to ... - IEA
refutes.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that current climate pledges are projected to increase global emissions by 10.6% by 2030 compared to 2010 levels, which contradicts the claim that emissions must be halved by that time to meet climate targets.
refutes.snippet: By 2035, emissions need to decline by 80% in advanced economies and 60% in emerging market and developing economies compared to the 2022 level. Current ...

refutes.title: Global Warming of 1.5 ºC —
refutes.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that current climate pledges are projected to increase emissions by 10.6% by 2030 compared to 2010 levels, which contradicts the claim that emissions must be halved by that time to meet climate targets.
refutes.snippet: Chapter 2. Showing how emissions can be brought to zero by mid-century stay within the small remaining carbon budget for limiting global warming to 1.5°C.

supports.title: Net Zero by 2050 – Analysis - IEA
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that to meet climate targets, global emissions must be reduced by 45% by 2030, which aligns with the claim that emissions should be at half of their 2010 levels by that time. This is supported by the need to limit global warming to 1.5°C as outlined in the Paris Agreement.
supports.snippet: To reach net zero emissions by 2050, annual clean energy investment worldwide will need to more than triple by 2030 to around $4 trillion. This ...

supports.title: USA - Climate Action Tracker
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that to meet climate targets, global emissions must be reduced by 45% by 2030, which aligns with the claim that emissions need to be halved from 2010 levels. This is supported by the assertion that significant reductions are necessary to limit global warming to 1.5°C, as outlined in the Paris Agreement.
supports.snippet: Under the Trump Administration, US emissions will decrease by 19%–30% in 2030 below 2005 levels, excluding emissions from land use change and forestry (LULUCF) ...

mixed.title: Climate Plans Remain Insufficient: More Ambitious Action Needed ...
mixed.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that CO2 emissions need to be cut by 45% by 2030 compared to 2010 levels, aligning with the claim that emissions must be halved to meet climate targets. However, current commitments are projected to increase emissions by 10.6% by 2030, showing insufficient action towards this goal.
mixed.snippet: The UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change's 2018 report indicated that CO2 emissions needed to be cut 45% by 2030, compared to 2010 ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Earth's weather cycles have become increasingly erratic and severe in recent years.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources, including NASA and NOAA, consistently indicate that climate change is leading to an increase in the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events, supporting the claim that Earth's weather cycles have become more erratic and severe in recent years.

supports.title: Billion-Dollar Weather and Climate Disasters
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that as Earth's climate changes, the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events are increasing, supporting the claim that weather cycles have become more erratic and severe in recent years.
supports.snippet: The US sustained 403 weather and climate disasters from 1980–2024 where overall damages/costs reached or exceeded $1 billion (including CPI adjustment to 2024).

supports.title: Evidence - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that Earth's climate is changing rapidly due to human activities, leading to increased temperatures and more frequent extreme weather events, which supports the claim of erratic and severe weather cycles in recent years.
supports.snippet: There is unequivocal evidence that Earth is warming at an unprecedented rate. Human activity is the principal cause.

supports.title: Extreme Weather and Climate Change - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events are increasing due to climate change, which aligns with the claim about erratic and severe weather cycles in recent years.
supports.snippet: Record-breaking heat waves on land and in the ocean, drenching rains, severe floods, years-long droughts, extreme wildfires, and widespread ...

supports.title: Are major natural disasters increasing? - USAFacts
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events are increasing due to climate change, which supports the claim that Earth's weather cycles have become more erratic and severe in recent years.
supports.snippet: The number of natural weather disasters with damages of more than a billion dollars has increased over the last forty years.

supports.title: Climate change impacts - NOAA
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that Earth's weather patterns are becoming more erratic and severe, as shown by the increasing number of record high temperatures and intense rainfall events in the U.S. since 1950, which supports the claim about the erratic nature of recent weather cycles.
supports.snippet: Changes in weather and climate patterns put lives at risk in many ways: Heat is one of the most deadly weather conditions. As ocean temperatures rise ...

supports.title: The Earth Experienced Another Year of Record Warming. The ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that Earth's climate is changing rapidly, with significant increases in temperature and extreme weather events, supporting the claim that weather cycles have become more erratic and severe in recent years.
supports.snippet: The year 2024 set an ominous heat record, as global average temperatures rose more than 1.5°C (2.7°F) above pre-industrial levels for the first time.

claim_reports.claim_text: Heat waves have more than doubled in duration in the past 50 years.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources indicate that heat waves have significantly increased in duration over the past 50 years, with one source noting a 45-day increase in the heat wave season since the 1960s. This strongly supports the claim that heat waves have more than doubled in duration.

supports.title: Increasing trends in regional heatwaves - PMC - PubMed Central
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that heatwaves have increased in frequency, duration, and intensity since the 1950s, with trends accelerating over the decades. This supports the claim that heat waves have more than doubled in duration in the past 50 years, as the study shows significant increases in heatwave duration and frequency across various regions.
supports.snippet: At least one extra heatwave day has occurred each decade over the majority of regions between 1950 and 2017 (though this can be as high as 3−5 ...

supports.title: Heat Waves in the Age of Climate Change: Longer, More Frequent ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the duration of heat waves has increased, with the heat wave season now lasting 45 days longer than it did in the 1960s, which supports the claim that heat waves have more than doubled in duration over the past 50 years.
supports.snippet: Nationwide, the time period in which heat waves might be expected to occur is 45 days longer than it was in the 1960s, according to the U.S. ...

supports.title: Once-in-50-year heat waves now happening every decade - Reuters
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that heat wave frequency and duration have increased over the past several decades, aligning with the claim that heat waves have more than doubled in duration in the past 50 years.
supports.snippet: Extreme heat waves that previously only struck once every 50 years are now expected to happen once per decade because of global warming, ...

mixed.title: Heat Waves and Climate Change | Union of Concerned Scientists
mixed.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that while heat waves have increased in frequency and intensity, it does not explicitly confirm that their duration has more than doubled in the past 50 years. It mentions a study showing an increase in extreme heat stress days but does not quantify the duration of heat waves specifically.
mixed.snippet: Extreme heat now and in the recent past​​ The Dust Bowl era of the 1930s holds the record for peak frequency, intensity, and duration of heat ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Droughts are becoming more common and severe in some areas due to climate change.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that droughts are becoming more common and severe due to climate change. Multiple high-reliability sources, including the U.S. Geological Survey and NASA, indicate that rising temperatures and increased atmospheric evaporative demand are exacerbating drought conditions, with significant trends observed in various regions, particularly the Western United States.

supports.title: Chapter 4 - Climate Change in Colorado Report
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that warmer temperatures due to climate change are likely contributing to more frequent and severe droughts, as droughts are worsened in a warmer climate and have shown upward trends in Colorado.
supports.snippet: Regardless of changes in precipitation, it is likely that warmer temperatures will contribute to more frequent and severe droughts. Warmer temperatures will ...

supports.title: Droughts and Climate Change | U.S. Geological Survey - USGS.gov
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that climate change is exacerbating droughts by increasing atmospheric evaporative demand, making them more severe and frequent. A study cited in the article shows that droughts have become 40% more severe globally over the past 40 years due to this increased demand for moisture from the atmosphere.
supports.snippet: Drought is a serious environmental threat across the United States. Climate change exacerbates droughts by making them more frequent, longer, and more severe.

supports.title: Extreme Weather and Climate Change - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that climate change is contributing to the increasing frequency and severity of droughts, particularly in the Western United States, due to rising temperatures and changing precipitation patterns.
supports.snippet: Record-breaking heat waves on land and in the ocean, drenching rains, severe floods, years-long droughts, extreme wildfires, and widespread ...

supports.title: Study: heat, not lack of precipitation, is driving western U.S. droughts
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that droughts are becoming more severe due to increased atmospheric evaporative demand driven by climate change, even in regions where precipitation levels have not decreased. This suggests that climate change is indeed contributing to the severity of droughts.
supports.snippet: They predict that droughts will last longer, cover wider areas and become more severe as the climate warms. Historically, drought in the ...

supports.title: Warming Makes Droughts, Extreme Wet Events More Frequent ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that droughts are becoming more severe due to increased atmospheric evaporative demand, which has risen faster than precipitation rates, leading to drier conditions globally.
supports.snippet: Scientists have predicted that droughts and floods will become more frequent and severe as our planet warms and climate changes, ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Individual rainfall events are becoming heavier across the world, falling in shorter and more intense bursts.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence from multiple high-reliability sources consistently indicates that individual rainfall events are becoming heavier and more intense, particularly due to climate change. Key sources such as the University of Michigan and NASA confirm significant increases in the frequency and severity of rainfall events over the past century.

supports.title: Extreme Precipitation | GLISA - University of Michigan
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that rainfall events are indeed becoming heavier and more intense, with significant increases in frequency and severity noted over the past century, particularly in certain regions of the US. This aligns with the claim that individual rainfall events are falling in shorter and more intense bursts.
supports.snippet: The frequency and intensity of severe storms has increased. This trend will likely continue as the effects of climate change become more pronounced.

supports.title: When it rains, it pours: How climate change fuels heavier rains
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that rainfall events are indeed becoming heavier and more frequent, particularly in the US, with a noted increase in the intensity of extreme rainfall events due to climate change.
supports.snippet: Recent research now suggests that extreme rainfall events will continue to increase in frequency and intensity across the nation, including in the Northeast.

supports.title: How does climate change affect precipitation? - NASA GPM
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that rainfall events are indeed becoming heavier and more frequent, particularly in the US, with significant increases in the intensity of rainstorms over the past century, especially in certain regions.
supports.snippet: Increased evaporation will result in more frequent and intense storms, but will also contribute to drying over some land areas.

supports.title: 'Biggest, baddest' rainfall events are getting worse - E&E News
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence supports the claim that individual rainfall events are becoming heavier and more intense due to rising temperatures, which intensify the Earth's water cycle and lead to more frequent and intense storms.
supports.snippet: A warmer atmosphere can hold more water, which makes it more likely moisture-laden clouds will drop rainfall bombs when they burst.

supports.title: Extreme Precipitation in a Warming Climate
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that rising temperatures are intensifying the water cycle, leading to more frequent and intense storms, which supports the claim that individual rainfall events are becoming heavier and more intense.
supports.snippet: Climate change is supercharging the water cycle, bringing heavier precipitation extremes — and related flood risks — across the U.S..

supports.title: The intensification of short-duration rainfall extremes due to climate ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that climate warming is leading to an increase in extreme rainfall events, which supports the claim that individual rainfall events are becoming heavier and more intense.
supports.snippet: Climate warming is driving an increase in extreme rainfall across most of the globe, increasing the likelihood of extreme rainfall events occurring (Donat et al ...

claim_reports.claim_text: The 1.5 degrees Celsius target is increasingly moving out of reach due to ongoing extreme weather events.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence presents a mixed view on the claim. While all sources acknowledge that individual years may exceed the 1.5°C threshold, they also emphasize that this does not render the long-term goal unattainable. However, they highlight the urgency of climate action in light of ongoing extreme weather events, suggesting that while the target is still possible, the situation is precarious.

mixed.title: 1.5 Degrees C: Understanding World's Critical Warming Threshold
mixed.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that while individual years may exceed the 1.5°C threshold, this does not mean the long-term goal is unattainable. However, the ongoing extreme weather events and record temperatures highlight the urgency of climate action to stay on track for the 1.5°C target.
mixed.snippet: Holding global warming to 1.5 degrees C has been the world's North Star for climate action — a critical benchmark against which policies are ...

mixed.title: Global Warming of 1.5 ºC —
mixed.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that while individual years may exceed the 1.5°C threshold, this does not mean the long-term goal of limiting global warming to 1.5°C is unattainable. However, the ongoing extreme weather events and record temperatures highlight the urgency of climate action to stay on track.
mixed.snippet: For oceans, regional surface temperature means and extremes are projected to be higher at 2°C compared to 1.5°C of global warming (high confidence).

mixed.title: The world is likely to exceed a key global warming target soon. Now ...
mixed.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that while individual years may exceed the 1.5°C threshold, this does not mean the long-term goal of limiting warming to 1.5°C is unattainable. However, the ongoing extreme weather events and record temperatures highlight the urgency of climate action to stay on track.
mixed.snippet: within the next decade, global temperatures will likely exceed 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels. leading to a surge in droughts, floods, ...

transcript_data.text: from flooding to heat waves wildfires to droughts our planet has been experiencing more frequent and intense weather events in recent years so how is this connected to climate change and how can we lessen its impact this is decomplicated how is extreme weather connected to climate change Earth's weather Cycles have shown signs of becoming increasingly more erratic severe and prolonged and though there is no blanket explanation for this change of weather patterns human-induced global warming is a major underlying Factor increased human consumption of fossil fuels since the industrial revolution has led to more greenhouse gases being released such as carbon dioxide and methane into Earth's atmosphere this has contributed to climate change in the form of increased global temperatures which can then affect How likely and how intense an extreme weather event can be the causality between global climate change and individual extreme weather event varies from event to event based on the type of weather the location time of year and how intense widespread and long it is however not all events are becoming more likely and severe some may be decreased in Chance by climate change or may not be changed much and changes are irregular across the world foreign what are some examples of extreme weather there are four main examples of extreme weather heat waves wildfires droughts and increased rainfall heat waves in many parts of the world are getting hotter more frequent and lasting longer and this is a result of human cause climate change hot spells have more than doubled in duration in the past 50 years and it's estimated that heat waves are 10 times more likely now according to the UK's Met Office increased heat has contributed to more regular and extensive Wildfire seasons in some areas of all continents this is because more moisture is drawn out of the earth and vegetation by more frequent and intense heat waves this then provides ideal kindling conditions for wildfires human activities such as Forest management and ignition sources are also important causal factors for these events droughts are becoming more common and more severe in some areas due to climate change there are two main ways this happens firstly through evaporation as the atmosphere warms more evaporation from the land occurs secondly through rainfall individual rainfall events are becoming heavier across the world falling in shorter and more intense bursts this heavier rain is more likely to saturate the ground and run directly into rivers rather than sustaining soil moisture and groundwater Reserve during more moderate rainfall overall the combination of more evaporation more sporadic heavier rainfall and less average downpours make dry spells more common in drought prone regions and seasons droughts put added pressure on Water Supplies as demand increases from people in agriculture which can lead to shortages human Water Management can also impact the likelihood of droughts increased rainfall has affected most of the world due to human-course climate change typically hot weather creates moisture and water vapor in the air which turns into droplets to create rain the warmer it becomes the more Vapor there is in the atmosphere this results in more droplets and heavier rainfall sometimes in a shorter space of time and over a small area this increased rainfall worsens flooding which can damage infrastructure and contaminate groundwater making it unsafe to drink however flooding can also be caused by human factors such as water management and defenses how can we lessen this impact scientists and experts have warned that if we want to reduce the worst consequences of climate breakdown we need to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius this target was written into the 2015 Paris agreement a legally binding treaty that 196 parties agreed to uphold the goal is to limit global warming to well below 2 degrees Celsius preferably to 1.5 degrees celsius compared to pre-industrial levels this Baseline was partly chosen because it's the earliest period with near Global observations in order to keep temperatures under 1.5 degrees Celsius dramatic changes need to be made namely Global CO2 emissions must be at half of their 2010 Levels by 2030 and at Net Zero or as close to no total carbon emissions as possible by 2050. the 1.5 degrees Celsius Target is increasingly Moving Out Of Reach an extreme weather is continuing to become more frequent and prevalent globally these multiple climate impacts will likely worsen a host of issues people around the world are currently facing like food insecurity damaged infrastructure induced migration and constrained resources however there is still hope that we can minimize the destructive cycles of extreme weather but in order to do so we must focus on limiting any further human impact on our Global Climate immediately [Music]

scientists and experts have warned that
if we want to reduce the worst
consequences of climate breakdown we
need to limit global warming to 1.5
degrees Celsius
this target was written into the 2015
Paris agreement a legally binding treaty
that 196 parties agreed to uphold the
goal is to limit global warming to well
below 2 degrees Celsius preferably to
1.5 degrees celsius compared to
pre-industrial levels this Baseline was
partly chosen because it's the earliest
period with near Global observations
in order to keep temperatures under 1.5
degrees Celsius dramatic changes need to
be made namely Global CO2 emissions must
be at half of their 2010 Levels by 2030
and at Net Zero or as close to no total
carbon emissions as possible by 2050.
